11:10 am
BE11:10am

And since we weren't here yesterday let's get some Pyrrhic victory stuff up.

BE11:11am

The offer of £17.28 per share values Sky at an Enterprise Value of some £35.7bn, or 14.8x June 2018 EBITDA. Put another way, Comcast is paying £1,554 ($2,031) per subscriber. Sky has 23.01m retail subscribers, with UK/Ireland at 13.0m (ARPU £45 p/m), Germany/Austria at 5.2m (ARPU €32 p/m), and Italy at 4.8m (ARPU €45 p/m). With a blended ARPU of £34.4 p/m, the acquisition price per subscriber equates to 3.8 years of revenue/subscriber.

BE11:11am

That's RBC.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

And in terms of the bump potential .....

Flaneur Morn' all. Will this be the week that BoJ assets reach 100% of GDP?
BE11:12am

Comcast needs more than 50% of shareholders to approve the deal. However, Fox (or rather Disney which is in the process of buying Fox’s legacy assets) has not yet indicated whether it intends to tender its shares. Comcast effectively needs 82% of the Non-Fox shares (61%) to accept Comcast’s offer. If that happens and Fox/Disney does not tender its shares, Comcast will be left with a stake of between 50%-61%, with Fox as the minority shareholder. Comcast would be unable to de-list Sky (threshold 75%) or squeeze out (threshold 90%). This could be used as leverage by Disney in return for distribution rights, or as part of any future asset swap.

VV75 morning
BE11:12am

And for the competition ......

11:12 am
BE11:12am

What price for Sky’s UK telecom assets? An acquirer is likely to want to raise prices, as the telecom part of the bundle is near marginal cost, in our view. Alternatively, if the buyer is bound by a long-term price freeze (as part of the sale conditions) this is likely to lead to lower sale proceeds. If we assume £650 per broadband sub (a 30% premium to TalkTalk’s £495 per sub), this would value Sky’s c.6.0m broadband subs at c.£3.9bn, adding on say c.£500m for the nascent Mobile MVNO business would value Sky’s telecom assets at c.£4.5bn, allowing it to lower the overall purchase cost by c.12.5%.
Implications for the UK operators. In our view, the acquisition by Comcast, assuming it gets approval, is a negative for the other UK operators compared to the alternative of Disney. Comcast has considerable scale and operational experience as a telecom/cable operator. It could use this to invest aggressively in both fixed and mobile in the UK, increasing the competitive pressure on existing operators.
Sale of UK Telecoms assets? The alternative is a sale of the assets which could be sold to either a financial or industrial buyer. In our view, an existing UK fixed line operator is unlikely. BT, Virgin Media and Talk Talk are too large, in our view, for antitrust approval. In addition, TalkTalk, the smallest of these does not have sufficient headroom on its balance sheet. We believe the only rational UK operators that could potentially bid are Telefonica’s O2 and Hutchison’s “3”. The logic for both operators is the same – they both have large mobile businesses but do not have any fixed line. Combining the two would offer convergence benefits to customers and significant cross selling opportunities with large synergies. However, we don’t think Telefonica is likely to buy Sky’s fixed line business due to Telefonica’s leverage which it has been seeking to reduce. In addition it exited the UK broadband business several years ago selling its broadband business - to Sky. That leaves the only UK player with sufficient scale as Hutchison. It is unclear whether Hutchison wants to pursue this.

BE11:19am

Medium-term targets ROCE to more than 15% by FY21, increasing to more than 20% by FY23; Operating Margin target at least 15% by FY21; cumulative cash savings FY19-21 at least £90m; reduction in Working Capital of at least £70m by FY21. The group is also looking to increase the range of services offered to its customers, increase the choice of tenure options and increase affordability through product design changes and cost savings. At 121p, McCarthy trades on a CY18 P/B of 0.9x, a 36% discount to the sector, and offers a yield of 2.9% (sector average 7.4%).

11:20 am

The update essentially presents a change of mindset for the business, with the focus turning away from growth and towards improving returns and margins over the next three financial years, as well as generating cash.

BE11:22am

Might work, I guess, given there's undoubtedly demand if they can meet it. I've noticed people talking about moving their grannies into a McCarthy, which is probably a positive more than a negative.

BE11:22am

11:22 am
BE11:22am

The renewed focus on delivering an improvement in returns and margins rather than growing the business makes sense to us in the current market. Clearly, in the absence of a change in government policy, the secondary market is expected to remain sluggish and unhelpful for the foreseeable future. Rightsizing the business and generating cash would seem to be the obvious and sensible strategy to pursue. We understand that the FY2021 targets are deliverable in the absence of any help from government policy on ground rents. The cost savings look achievable and with little growth, cash generation should be good. The turnaround is unlikely to be as straightforward as it would be for a mainstream house-builder, given the lack of support from Help to Buy and the risk around the success and effectiveness of adjusting the customer proposition. Consensus should move up to reflect the clarity around the new targets.

BE11:23am

Dividend yield is c.4.5% which provides some valuation support. Clearly, achieving a ROCE of over 15% by FY2021 would support a re-rating of the shares but there is execution risk and the time taken to get there to take account of. The shares currently sit at a c.10% discount to book value for FY2019.

Given these positive moves to improve profitability and the resulting pick-up in ROCE/RoE, we feel more comfortable valuing the group on a small (15%) premium to NAV. As a result, we up our TP to 150p and retain our Buy recommendation

BE11:31am

Our first take is that the value proposition for RRS shareholders is limited given the nil-premium offer. Based on RRS’s premium rating, we calculate this would imply an equity ownership of ~40%. Furthermore, the 2018 dividend implies a yield of ~2.9% vs. our base case ~3.5%. However, we acknowledge African risks have become more acute recently, and the MergeCo likely offers greater liquidity, a larger production base & diversification by asset / geography which could be attractive to marginal shareholders. Given approval by both sets of Boards, we see limited chance of an interloper and downgrade our recommendation to Neutral.

We downgrade FY19 PBT/EPS forecasts by 20% to £34.9m/10.4p. This is on the assumption that market volatility continues to remain fairly benign.

BE11:39am

It has always been clear that the introduction of the new leverage rules was likely to cause a degree of market dislocation. Benign market conditions (also referenced by IG Group) has clearly exacerbated the effect. Looking beyond this short-term dislocation, we believe the imposition of tighter regulation is likely to prompt a consolidation of the market towards large players with well invested platforms such as CMC. In addition, CMC has shown the strength of its technology with the ANZ deal, where ANZ retail stockbroking clients have been successfully migrated and we will begin to see the benefit of this from next month. The shares trade on 7x EV/EBITDA. We place our target price under review but maintain our Buy recommendation given the longer term value inherent in CMC’s well invested trading platform.

Whilst Next H1 PBT is a 1% miss versus BBG consensus (recall that Q2/ H1 sales previously reported), trading in August and September has been better than expected by the company (which had accounted for some pull
forward into July in its previous guidance). As such it is raising the mid-point of FY 19 PBT guidance by c.1% With some investors becoming concerned that Next could reduce FY 19 guidance in light of the extended summer temperatures delaying the start to the AW season, we think the raised guidance will send the shares higher this morning. Furthermore, combined with comments from Debenhams yesterday that it has seen good outerwear sales through August (albeit supported by product improvements) this possibly suggests that the recent market backdrop has been less unsupportive than feared and as such as we would also expect MKS, ABF (Primark) and Asos to move higher today. On the broader outlook, management comments that it remains cautious for the rest of the year and notes that many structural and cyclical headwinds have not abated.

BE11:59am

Africa Oil’s stock has been a barometer for investor sentiment towards the South Lokichar oil discoveries it shares with Tullow Oil and Total. With an adjusted enterprise value that implies the 560mmbbls of gross 2C resources are valued at less than $1/bbl, we believe it is clear investors remain cautious on the partnership’s plans to sanction the development by late 2019. We attended Africa
Oil’s site visit last week with questions on project commerciality and financing plans. Although it was too early for definitive
answers, we came away optimistic that clear and credible answers can arrive in the coming months. Further encouragement was visible evidence of progress on the LAPSSET infrastructure
corridor that includes the proposed export pipeline route, with construction work at the Lamu port under way. With oil prices touching $80/bbl we expect investor attention to focus on
E&P stocks with credible growth opportunities and see the
South Lokichar project as one that can become increasingly credible over the coming months, driving a re-rating on investor valuations of the asset. We continue to rate both Africa Oil and Tullow Oil Overweight.

BE12:06pm

The company's quarterly filings showed net debt peaked at £1.3bn at December 2017 versus zero at September 2017, refecting the usual seasonal working capital swing. While the December gross cash was not revealed, this was £1.4bn at September 2017, and if we assume 80% of this was customer cash, it implies December 2017 cash was ~£0.3bn, and we forecast the same for December 2018, sufficient headroom we think (particularly with the new RCF providing additional liquidity). We forecast net debt will rise by around £200m this year, mostly reflecting the Co-op contingent payment, extra finance leases, and a one-off WC outflow (which should reverse in Q1 19). This implies adjusted gross leverage will rise from 3.5x to 3.8x from December 2017 to December 2018, its gross debt high point. The company does not reveal its covenants, and disclosure here in future would be helpful, but assuming a covenant of 4.0x implies the company would need to see another £30m (11%) EBIT downgrade, or a £130m (50%) increase in net debt, in order to trip covenants, and there should be a profit recovery from current depressed levels.

wayneJ (@BE - seriously I found it amusing that bosses (who are awarded millions in share options) object to the staff having awards.)
BE12:07pm

On balance we remain positive. TCG shares have dropped 54% this year, and we appreciate that risks remain high, that it has plenty to prove, and that positive catalysts are in short supply. However, after updating our price target for our downgrade (we continue to base on an average of peers, FCF and DCF), we see significant upside. Our price target drops 30% from 150p to 105p, more than our 20% forecast downgrades, and offering 88% potential upside. Our bear case assumes margins drop another 50bps to 2.5% in FY19, and we value this on a P/E of 8x, giving 20% potential downside. Our bull case is 160p, which assumes a return to FT17 margins, a very reasonable possibility given how unusual FY18 has been. On balance, we remain Overweight the shares.
